@guozhangwang hi,it was a little a little complicated.
1. In  #2322    missed docs/security.html 
2. changing OptionParser() to OptionParser(false)  to disable abbreviations. 
    The abbreviations function of OptionParser is not fit for kafka
    As described in the doc of Jopt Simple : You can abbreviate long options, so long as the abbreviation is unique.But most of Kafka command  has  duplicate prefix, OptionParser will parse  options in order, many times the results are not satisfactory.


    For example:
[root@xx15 bin]# ./kafka-console-producer.sh -r
r is not a recognized option
[root@xx15 bin]# ./kafka-console-producer.sh -t
t is not a recognized option
[root@xx15 bin]# ./kafka-console-producer.sh -v
Option value-serializer requires an argument
[root@xx15 bin]# ./kafka-console-producer.sh -k
Option key-serializer requires an argument
[root@xx15 bin]# ./kafka-console-producer.sh -s
s is not a recognized option


If  there are repeat options,the result is confused

@apurvam i don't think this works by adding another state. The state transitions are happening on the Producers thread, yet we don't know we have successfully completed a transactional request until we get an `AddPartitionsToTxnResponse` or an `AddOffsetsToPartitionResponse`, which is happening on the sender thread. In the meantime the current state may have transitioned to subsequent states _before_ we get these responses. So when it comes to the time when we need to decide if we should send the `EndTxnRequest` we don't have any idea if the transaction was previously in the `STARTING_TRANSACTION` state. I thought adding a `previousState` might help, but no. As there may have been multiple transitions

I didn't move the `IllegalStateException` handling into `ControllerEventManager` because it also clears some state that the event manager doesn't have access to. I did extract a method, which seems like a reasonable compromise. Let me know what you think.

When the kafka server is running, someone removed the index file on the disk manually, if at this point, the function AbstractIndex.Resize(newSize: Int) is triggered, will create a new ".index" file which the size is "roundedNewSize", but the content is empty.
I think if the ".index" is not exist when the function AbstractIndex.Resize(newSize: Int) running , we should copy the contents from old "mmap" to new "mmap" to avoid the "empty file".
@rajinisivaram, maybe you can review this one. It's a tiny change.
@cmccabe, can you please take a look?

@MarkTcMA Thanks for the patch! Are you familiar with the [KIP](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Kafka+Improvement+Proposals) process? I think a new tool like this will probably require KIP.

https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.11/4396/
Test FAILed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).

Let me summarize the changes in this patch. The main thing is a change in the compaction logic to _not_ preserve the base offset of each record batch. Previously if a record batch contained offsets [1,2,3] and if 1 was removed by the cleaner, the batch would still indicate 1 as its base offset. I couldn't think of a good reason to preserve the base offset from the original batch (we only need to ensure the last sequence is preserved for EoS) and it seemed a bit inconsistent with some of the actual usage. I therefore changed the behavior so that the new base offset always pointed to the offset of the first message (so it would be 2 using the example above). To reflect this change, I changed the name from "base offset" to "first offset". Similarly, I changed "base sequence" to "first sequence" and "base timestamp" to "first timestamp.

Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).

Going to close this since @junrao correctly pointed out that we must preserve the base sequence for deduplication. I will open a separate PR to add some comments on this point and fix some documentation inconsistencies.

@mjsax The EmbeddedKafkaCluster is not a secured cluster used in tests. Is there any integration test using EmbeddedKafkaCluster as secured? Because I need to set java.auth.login.config to pass to kafka brokers. Any info or example on this would help me. Thanks.

Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).
One other thing I noticed. The `lastError` field in `TransactionalRequestResult` seems like it should be `volatile`.
You can just specify the required configuration for the EmbeddedKafkaCluster. See here for more details: http://kafka.apache.org/documentation/#security_configbroker

One minor nit, instead of `validateKeyNotNull(key)` methods we could use `Objects.requireNonNull(key)` which throws a NPE if the passed in value is null.  But this is probably just my personal preference, I'm not sure it would better than what you have.

LGTM

@junrao Thanks for the review. Something else that occurred to me is that the recovery logic validates that messages do not exceed the max message size (they are considered corrupt if they do). With this change, we will need to loosen that checking. Perhaps we could ensure that messages are not more than twice the max message size or something like that?
